statement.p: In our algebra and calculus classes, where we worked in \Q and \R, all non-zero numbers had multiplicative inverses. For example, 5^{-1} = \frac15 since 5^{-1}\cdot 5 = 1. But \frac15 \not \in Z!

When we're working with only integers, in particular in congruence classes modulo an integer m, fractions aren't a thing. Some numbers, though, do have multiplicative inverses. They're special, and we explore them in this section.
Let a be an integer and m a positive integer. We define a multiplicative inverse of a modulo m to be an integer b such that ab \equiv 1 \pmod{m}.
Since 5\cdot 3 \equiv 1 \pmod{7}, we say that 3 is a multiplicative inverse of 5 modulo 7. Similarly, 5 is a multiplicative inverse of 3 modulo 7.

statement.p: Let's create a multiplication table modulo 9. The following Sage code does it for us. You can change the variable n to other numbers to quickly generate other multiplication tables.

The output is a table/matrix whose i, jth entry is i \cdot j \pmod{n}.
n = 9 rows = [] for i in range(1, n): rows.append(list(map((lambda x: (i*x)%n), [x for x in range(1,n)])))
table(rows)

If a \and m are relatively prime integers and m \gt 1, then an inverse of a modulo m exists.

ol.li: The inverse of a \text{ modulo } m is its Bezout coefficient in {\gcd(a,m) = as + mt}
The inverse is unique, but we won't prove that here.

What condition is required for a number a to have an inverse modulo n?
What is a condition on n for every element to have an inverse modulo n?

ol.li: To have an inverse modulo n, a number a must be relatively prime to n
To have the property that every number has an inverse modulo n, the number n must be prime
